Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Learned how to speak and write in French. I learned a lot about grammar and rules in writing and speaking, such as past and present tense.
Acquired foundational skill level of French and the ability to hold basic conversations.
I gained an understanding of basic French grammar and vocabulary.
I have become comfortable speaking conversational French and understanding French grammar.
The weekly quizzes were a lot sometimes, but watching and going over the video in class was helpful, as well as the workbook and ding worksheets in class that helped us prepare for the tests.

This course was fun and well-structured. New concepts and vocabulary were presented clearly and thoroughly, and questions were answered effectively. The only real weakness of the course is that it met every day, even during reading period. However, the class was enjoyable enough that this did not really pose an issue.
The course moved very quickly, but the material was reviewed regularly so it wasn't too overwhelming.

I think it would be helpful to have a more structured vocabulary list that we could reference week to week in preparation for the tests. I think I may have gotten behind in vocab because I didn't have something I could look back on and review.
If you do the homework and watch the videos, you will get the most out of the class.
The course is very engaging and gives great results, but is very confusing.
Yes, you have to be willing to put in the time and see the professor if you need help because it really does make a difference. They want you to succeed and understand French.

Yes, I would. It's a great way to learn French and although the workload is pretty high, the class does a great job of teaching you a lot of French in a short period of time. The videos are actually pretty amusing to watch after you get past the initial barrier of a foreign language. The class itself is small and pretty fun.
Yes. Although it was a lot of work, you come out of the course with basic proficiency in French, which I think is a very rewarding skill.
Yes, French is one of the better language programs for introductory students at Yale.
Yes. Although this class can be a lot of work, it is rewarding to see yourself improving rapidly.
Yes! Professor Ngame was very helpful and I looked forward to coming to class everyday!
it's a great class that teaches you a lot in a short class. it's challenging but you can do homework as it fits your schedule.
